gui

Class RangeSet

  • java.lang.Object
    • gui.RangeSet

  • public class RangeSet
extends java.lang.Object
    Class stores a set of ranges, i.e., intervals. Its single current user is the FirstPersonDrawer class. Note: remove and intersect methods operate on a set of elements, however there is no method to add more than a single element to the set as the set method removes all previous elements from the set. This only way to increase the cardinality is to split an existing interval into two by way of the remove method. This implies that ranges are disjoint and sorted in increasing order. This code is refactored code from Maze.java by Paul Falstad, www.falstad.com, Copyright (C) 1998, all rights reserved Paul Falstad granted permission to modify and use code for teaching purposes. Refactored by Peter Kemper

    • Method Detail

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Tells if the set is empty.
        Returns:
        true if the set is empty, false otherwise

      • set

        public void set(int lowerBound,
                int upperBound)
        Clears the set and fills it with a single new interval as specified
        Parameters:
        lowerBound - minimum value for new element
        upperBound - maximum value for new element

      • remove

        public void remove(int lowerBound,
                   int upperBound)
        Removes interval [lb,ub] from existing set such that none of its elements intersects with it anymore. Existing intervals are reduced if they intersect, split into two or fully removed if they are contained in [lb,ub]
        Parameters:
        lowerBound - is the lower bound lb of the interval
        upperBound - is the upper bound ub of the interval

      • getIntersection

        public int[] getIntersection(int lowerBound,
                             int upperBound)
        Computes an intersection of the given interval [lowerBound,upperBound] with the intervals in this set. If the given interval intersects with none, the method returns null. If it intersects with at least one interval, the intersection with the first interval in this set that does so is computed and returned. For intervals, the given bounds are included. So the given bounds in the result are both elements of the intersection.
        Parameters:
        lowerBound - gives the low end of the interval of interest
        upperBound - gives the high end of the interval of interest
        Returns:
        [lb,ub] with lower and upper bound for the intersection, null if there is none
